description:
Maniola hyperantus, commonly known as the Ringlet butterfly, is a species of Lepidoptera that belongs to the family Nymphalidae. This medium-sized butterfly is native to Europe and Asia, and is widely distributed across its range.

The Ringlet butterfly has distinctive brown-colored wings, with a series of eye-like spots or "rings" along the outer edge of the hindwings. These markings are believed to serve as a defense mechanism, deterring predators by making the butterfly appear larger and more threatening. The upperside of the wings is a uniform dark brown, while the underside is slightly paler and displays the characteristic eye-like spots more prominently.

The species undergoes a complete metamorphosis, with distinct egg, larval (caterpillar), pupal (chrysalis), and adult (butterfly) stages. The caterpillars feed on various grasses and are typically green or brown in color, blending in with the vegetation.

Maniola hyperantus is generally found in woodland, grassland, and scrubland habitats, where it plays an important role in the ecosystem as a pollinator, contributing to the reproduction of various plant species. The conservation status of the Ringlet butterfly is generally considered to be of Least Concern, as it is a widespread and adaptable species.
